content.question: Identical carts <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> are placed on a straight, horizontal track, where they are free to move with negligible friction in the axles of their wheels. The carts undergo two separate collisions. In Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> moves to the right with an initial kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> toward Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, which is at rest, and the carts collide elastically. After the collision, Cart <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> comes to rest, and Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> moves to the right. In Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> again moves to the right with the same initial kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> toward Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, which is at rest, but the carts stick together during the collision and then move together to the right. Is the speed of Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> greater immediately after Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> or immediately after Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> ? What reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Immediately after Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. During Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains an amount of kinetic energy equal to <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>, while in Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains an amount of kinetic energy less than <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>.

Immediately after Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. During Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains an amount of kinetic energy greater than <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>, while in Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains an amount of kinetic energy equal to <math alttext="K sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>.

Immediately after Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. In Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the two-cart system loses more kinetic energy than in Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Immediately after Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. When the carts stick together, Cart <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> transfers more energy to Cart <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> than when the carts bounce off of one another.
